for all you ladied who think the court order means the cops will protect you from an abusive ex-husband.
 
In a 7-2 decision, the Court ruled that local governments have no constitutional duty to protect from private violence an individual who is shielded by a court's restraining order. Such individuals do not gain an enforceable interest in that protection, the Court declared in an opinion by Justice Scalia. The case was Town of Castle Rock v. Gonzales (04-278).

 Nope.
 
 Prohibited weapons are weapons that are considered totally inappropriate for general possession or use because they are exclusively offensive in nature. Such weapons cannot be imported, manufactured, sold, possessed or carried.
 
 21. An article designed or adapted to discharge oleoresin capsicum spray.
 
 A few of the more ridiculous items listed are:
 
 22. An article designed or adapted to emit or discharge an offensive, noxious or irritant liquid, powder, gas or chemical so as to cause disability, incapacity or harm to another person. 
 
 23. An article designed or adapted to emit an electric current into a human body for the purposes of incapacitation or injury.
 
 24. An acoustic anti-personnel device that is designed to cause permanent or temporary incapacity or disability, or to otherwise physically disorientate a person.
 
 26. "Extendable baton", being a baton designed or adapted so that the length of the baton extends by gravity or centrifugal force or by any pressure applied to a button, spring or device in or attached to the handle of the baton.
 
 34. A hand-held battery-operated article commonly known as a "laser pointer" designed or adapted to emit a laser beam with an accessible emission limit of greater than 1 mW. 
 
 47. The martial arts weapon known as a "Tonfa". 
 
 4. "Dagger", being a sharp pointed stabbing instrument (other than an oyster knife), ordinarily capable of being concealed on the person and having:
 
 * a flat blade with cutting edges (whether serrated or not serrated) along the length of both sides; or
 * a needle-like blade, the cross section of which is elliptical or has 3 or more sides, but not including instruments such as swords or bayonets. 
 
 Needless to say, my governments attitude to self defense and prohibition of weapons leaves much to be desired, IMHO.

 Depending on the manner in which it is delivered. The ones that use a more stream than spray can take up to 30 seconds or more in my experience to work. The aerosalized stuff works qwiker, but it has less range. There are some nice pesticide sized spray cans that lay out anice aerosalized cone, but they aren't exactly concealable.
 
 Even the ones that work though, if they are within arms reach they will generally still be able to flail and potentially injure someone or hold on. I have rarely seen anyone who just drops when they are hit with it, although some do.

 Our sheriff's deputies use the taser for that very reason. Standard duty gear is two holsters, sidearm and taser. Anyone who is placing their safety in the hands of a keyring sized cannister of spray needs to talk to a LE member who has ruined uniforms and taken bruises subduing a sprayed suspect wound up on crank. While it may be difficult for general society believe it, there are a bunch of people out there who actually look forward to fighting with cops and consider civilians victims at best.

Adept

Depending on the manner in which it is delivered. The ones that use a more stream than spray can take up to 30 seconds or more in my experience to work. The aerosalized stuff works qwiker, but it has less range. There are some nice pesticide sized spray cans that lay out anice aerosalized cone, but they aren't exactly concealable.
 
 Even the ones that work though, if they are within arms reach they will generally still be able to flail and potentially injure someone or hold on. I have rarely seen anyone who just drops when they are hit with it, although some do.

 
 It also depends on the strength and, as you say, delivery. The spray ones are good, but outside with a breeze their range is extremely limited.
 
 If you get a can of that bear repellent I hear about, that should drop just about any human in a few seconds. Of course, I also hear that is a prohibited weapon (in Canada, I believe).
 
 I personally believe OC sprays are a better tool for selfe defense. Tasers work by jabbing small darts into the flesh, and administering an electric current. The darts won't penetrate to the flesh if someone is wearing a jacket or thick clothing. Especially in large parts of the northern hemisphere, this limits tasers to a small range of effectiveness during the colder months.
 
 Like anything, research needs to be done on the choice of OC spray or taser, and you need to train in it's use. Buying a keyring sized cannister of pepper spray and believing it will protect you is like buying a .357, leaving it locked in it's case in the cupboard in the office and thinking of it as a tool for home defense.
 
 http://www.martialtalk.com/forum/showthread.php?t=22969&page=1&pp=15
 
 A link on the topic of OC spray that some might find interesting.
SymonTemplar

Actually Taser prongs need not be in the skin to deliver the charge. As long as they are within 1.25" of the skin the charge will arc. In addition Taser offers a cold weather dart that is a longer dart for penetrating through heavy clothing.
